item.title: Zypr Releases API That Lets You Control Your Favorite Web Services With Your Voice
item.description: Zypr Releases API That Lets You Control Your Favorite Web Services With Your Voice: Pioneer Electronics today a... http://bit.ly/iBchBS
item.content:encoded: Zypr Releases API That Lets You Control Your Favorite Web Services With Your Voice: Pioneer Electronics today a... http://bit.ly/iBchBS Pioneer Electronics today announced a nifty new service called Zypr, a platform that collects your favorite web services all in one place and allows you to control them using your voice -- on any connected device. Today, our experience of the Web is fragmented across devices, as we use each device, be it a phone, tablet, etc, for their traditional uses, yet each of them is connected but few of them are cooperating. Zypr's API is designed to simplify device connectivity to the many devices and applications we use on a daily basis, including in-vehicle entertainment, tablets, TVs, and smartphone apps, aggregating them in a single portal, under a single account. It's a consistent way to access voice UI, maps and routing, local search, social networking, music, radio, etc. from your car, from home, from work, or on your smartphone at the grocery store. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

Click the little +1 and tell everyone you liked a particular search result. Tweet Then they announced the +1 button. Click that and tell your network about a page you like, right from that page. You don’t have to be on Google.com. Note that I even have it on this post, over on the right >> But now, the internet marketing world has gone insane. Even more insane than usual. item.title: 500Friends Allows Retailers To Reward Customers For Social Actions
item.description: 500Friends Allows Retailers To Reward Customers For Social Actions http://tcrn.ch/mDk1HP by @leenarao
item.content:encoded: 500Friends Allows Retailers To Reward Customers For Social Actions http://tcrn.ch/mDk1HP by @leenarao Consumers are engaging retailers on Facebook and Twitter now more than ever. Whether it is Liking a deal, Tweeting the link to a product, or even participating in a contest, shoppers are mentioning and interacting with these e-commerce sites on a daily basis. The problem with traditional online loyalty programs mirror offline programs, they only focus on rewarding users for simply their purchases. The challenge for retailers is not only how to track online mentions, but also how to meaningfully reward consumers for these mentions. Enter Y Combinator-backed 500Friends, which offers a platform called Loyalty Plus, which allows retailers to reward their customers for social actions. The SaaS allows retailers to track users Tweeting their purchases, Liking the Facebook page and referring friends. It also allows merchants to reward other actions such as writing product reviews, entering sweepstakes or signing up to newsletters. Each action gives the user points, which can be used towards discounts, or even put towards charity donations. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

item.title: Heyzap Brings Social Discovery And Check-In For Games To The iPhone
item.description: Heyzap Brings Social Discovery And Check-In For Games To The iPhone http://tcrn.ch/lQB5mp by @ripemp
item.content:encoded: Heyzap Brings Social Discovery And Check-In For Games To The iPhone http://tcrn.ch/lQB5mp by @ripemp Heyzap, a social discovery platform for mobile and online games, announced today that it’s zapping its way onto the iPhone just in time for WWDC 2011, Apple's developer conference. The startup will be extending its fast-growing Android community (which launched in March) and has been doubling in size every month since. The startup’s new iPhone app will detect recent gameplay and lets users check-in to their favorite games. Once checked-in, Heyzap users can share scores and more on Facebook and Twitter and see what games their friends are playing. Mobile gamers can now check-in to all 65K games on iOS and all 10K games on Android. Huzzah! Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

item.title: Facebook VP Chamath Palihapitiya Forms New Venture Fund, The Social+Capital Partnership
item.description: Facebook VP Chamath Palihapitiya Forms New Venture Fund, The Social+Capital Partnership http://tcrn.ch/iJQiGU by @arrington
item.content:encoded: Facebook VP Chamath Palihapitiya Forms New Venture Fund, The Social+Capital Partnership http://tcrn.ch/iJQiGU by @arrington Facebook vice president Chamath Palihapitiya will leave the company as he launches a large new venture fund called The Social+Capital Partnership, with backing from some of the worlds leading business and technology leaders. The new fund will be up to $400 million in size, he says, and will focus on a wide range of investments in technology, healthcare, education and financial services. Investors in the fund are not yet being disclosed, although Palihapitiya is the largest single limited partner. Facebook is also investing, says the company. Palihapitiya, who joinedFacebook in 2007 and led the launch of the Facebook platform, has been investing for the last several years through a fund called Embarcadero Ventures. Not all of his investments through that fund have been disclosed, but they include Playdom, Peixe Urbano, Pure Storage, Yammer and others. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

item.title: How Facebook Can Put Google Out of Business
item.description: How Facebook Will Put Google Out of Business http://tcrn.ch/lMcxYt by @erickschonfeld
item.content:encoded: How Facebook Will Put Google Out of Business http://tcrn.ch/lMcxYt by @erickschonfeld I was surprised to hear former Google CEO Eric Schmidt publicly lament lost opportunities and missed chances to catch Facebook the other day. I used to envy Google and the vast digital empire that Schmidt commanded.  Google had one of the most intricate monopolies of all time. It had the most impressive dataset the world had ever seen; the most sophisticated algorithm to make sense of it; an audience of a billion users expressing their interest; and more than a million advertisers bidding furiously to reach those consumers at just the right moment. And that’s why I used to think that Google was unstoppable. Until I realized one very important thing: Google’s revered and unparalleled dataset is increasingly dating itself as an ossified relic akin to the Dead Sea Scrolls—outshined by the freshness of the living, breathing organism that is the social Web. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

item.content:encoded: Here We Go Again: Syria Goes Offline http://tcrn.ch/kd2v7j by @alexia After Egypt and Libya this spring, Syria is the latest Middle Eastern/North African country to get its connectivity pulled due to internal anti-governmental unrest. According to the Rensys blog almost 2/3rds of Syrian networks have been pulled as of late last night. It seems like killing the Internet is the MENA government default when it comes to quelling protests. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

item.title: Apple Hires The Guy Who Hacked Together A Better iOS Notifications System
item.description: Apple Hires The Guy Who Hacked Together A Better iOS Notifications System http://tcrn.ch/mHPI9L by @grg
item.content:encoded: Apple Hires The Guy Who Hacked Together A Better iOS Notifications System http://tcrn.ch/mHPI9L by @grg Back in February, I wrote that MobileNotifier (a replacement notifications system for jailbroken iOS devices) would be the one thing that would make anyone want to jailbreak — and I stand by it. Months later, my iPhone is still jailbroken, almost solely so that I don't have to go back to Apple's built-in system. It seems I'm not the only one who was impressed. Sometime in the last week or so — just days before they announce iOS 5, which is expected to come complete with a new (and hopefully less terrible) notifications system — Apple has pulled MobileNotifier's developer, Peter Hajas, under their wing. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

item.title: Don’t Influence, Connect And Build Trust
item.description: Don’t Influence, Connect And Build Trust http://bit.ly/juJIgB #socialmedia
item.content:encoded: Don’t Influence, Connect And Build Trust http://bit.ly/juJIgB #socialmedia Many continue an unhealthy obsession with influence. Except the web isn't really about influence. It never was. The mere fact so many use influence as jargon of choice to define their web startups which tout ability to show how important someone is shows a lack of comprehension of the nature of web communities. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: thefuturebuzz.com

item.title: Revenge of the Travel Agent: Jetsetter Announces Travel Planning Service (And Discounts for TechCrunch Readers)
item.description: Revenge of the Travel Agent: Jetsetter Announces Travel Planning Service (And Discounts for Tec.. http://tcrn.ch/kRuubf by @sarahcuda
item.content:encoded: Revenge of the Travel Agent: Jetsetter Announces Travel Planning Service (And Discounts for Tec.. http://tcrn.ch/kRuubf by @sarahcuda A few days ago at the All Things D conference, Marc Andreessen predicted that every wacky 1999 dot com business that failed would one day find success in a new incarnation. But what about businesses those dot coms killed? Jetsetter is launching a personal travel planning service today that is essentially a travel agent 2.0. Thankfully, the earlier iteration of online travel sites so decimated the category that Jetsetter has a pretty wide open market opportunity here. A poll of its users found that 90% of them had never used a travel agent and wouldn't even know where to find one. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

item.title: Why Daily Deals Are Becoming A Raw Deal
item.description: Why Daily Deals Are Becoming A Raw Deal http://tcrn.ch/lcPGhU
item.content:encoded: Why Daily Deals Are Becoming A Raw Deal http://tcrn.ch/lcPGhU In the wake of Groupon's IPO filing, it's worth looking at the fundamentals of the offer. Growth numbers to date have been phenomenal. But is it a business that can last? We love daily deals for a simple reason: the deals have been outstanding. If revenue growth in the first Internet bubble was about selling a dollar for 50 cents, growth in the daily deals business has been about getting other people to sell their dollars for 50 cents and charging them 25 cents for the privilege. The deals have been embarrassingly good. I used the first Google Offers deal at Floyd's Coffee yesterday. For $3, I got $10 worth of food. Let me tell you, it's really hard to spend $10 in a coffee shop. I got an order of red beans and rice, a Mexican Coke, a doughnut and a chocolate chip cookie. The total came to $9.95. That's a great deal for me, but it's unsustainable for the business. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

item.title: Did a pork-coated bullet kill Bin Laden? Yes, says firm who claim its pig fat gun oil is bought by U.S. military personnel | Mail Online
item.description: http://bit.ly/ikoG14 Did bullet covered in pig fat really kill Osama? Yes states military ordnance makers Silver Bullet Gun company
item.content:encoded: http://bit.ly/ikoG14 Did bullet covered in pig fat really kill Osama? Yes states military ordnance makers Silver Bullet Gun company The makers of Silver Bullet Gun Oil claim it contains 13 per cent USDA liquefied pig fat thus making the product 'a highly effective counter-Islamic terrorist force multiplier.', The makers of Silver Bullet Gun Oil claim it contains 13 per cent USDA liquefied pig fat thus making the product 'a highly effective counter-Islamic terrorist force multiplier.'
